newsitem.title: CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: Fresh Bangui clash, three killed.
newsitem.headline: Fresh Bangui clash, three killed.

text.p: African peacekeepers in the Central African Republic opened fire on Saturday, killing three mutineers and wounding several others, a spokesman for the multinational force said.
The clash was the most serious since President Ange-Felix Patasse and his rivals agreed an African-mediated peace plan in January to end the country's third army mutiny in under a year.

The commander of the InterAfrican Surveillance Mission for the Bangui Accords MISAB, General Nkili Edjo, said in a statement that unit had acted in self-defence and stressed the neutrality of the force.
He warned all sides in the conflict against undermining the peace accords by force.
"This warning is not in out direction only, it is addressed to all parties to the conflict," he said.
Nkili expressed regret at the incident and appealed to civilians not to rally to armed groups and allow themselves to be used as human shields against peacekeepers.
The spokesman told Reuters that the peacekeepers, who took over from French troops last month to act as a buffer between the rival forces, had opened fire after mutineers tried to loot petrol.
Nkili's statement referred to "an armed and uncontrolled group" and said that it had opened fire on peacekeepers protecting a petrol pumping operation.
Residents said the sound of gunshots, including heavy weapons fire, could be heard in the capital for much of the day. Calm returned later.
The first mutinies last April and May began over pay and conditions but turned into a campaign to oust Patasse, a northern civilian who won 1993 presidential elections.
The latest mutiny, which began on November 15, degenerated into ethnic bloodshed. French troops, in the country under a defence pact, restored order.
The conflict pitted the mutineers, mainly southerners from the minority Yakoma tribe of former military ruler Andre Kolingba, against Patasse's presidential guard.
All eight soldiers and 11 civilians still detained after the latest unrest were released on March 17 under an amnesty.
The amnesty, signed by Patasse, gave all mutineers until March 30 to hand over their weapons or fail to qualify.
Patasse formed a government of national unity under the peace deal but his supporters hold the main portfolios. Friction has continued between Patasse and the mutineers.
Witnesses had reported sporadic gunfire from rebel strongholds earlier this month.
